title: litterfitter
text: moment one key function fit_litter can fit 6 different types decomposition trajectories. Note fitted object litfit object can visually compare fits different non-linear equations plot_multiple_fits function:  Calling plot litfit object show data, curve fit, even equation, estimated coefficients:  summary litfit object show summary statistics fit. litfit object can see uncertainty parameter estimate bootstrapping
code: library(litterfitter) fit <- fit_litter(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),                   mass.remaining =c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),                   model="weibull",                   iters=500)  class(fit) plot_multiple_fits(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),                    mass.remaining=c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),                    model=c("neg.exp","weibull"),                    iters=500) plot(fit) #> Summary of litFit object #> Model type: weibull  #> Number of observations:  7  #> Parameter fits: 4.19  #> Parameter fits: 2.47  #> Time to 50% mass loss: 3.61  #> Implied steady state litter mass: 3.71 in units of yearly input  #> AIC:  -3.8883  #> AICc:  -0.8883  #> BIC:  -3.9965

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cornwell. Author, maintainer. James Weedon. Author. Guofang Liu. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cornwell WK, Weedon JT (2014). “Decomposition trajectories diverse litter types: model selection analysis.” Methods Ecology Evolution, 5, 173-182. https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.12138.
code: @Article{,   title = {Decomposition trajectories of diverse litter types: a model selection analysis},   author = {William K. Cornwell and James T. Weedon},   journal = {Methods in Ecology and Evolution},   year = {2014},   volume = {5},   pages = {173-182},   url = {https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.12138}, }

title: Fits a Collection of Curves to Single-Cohort Decomposition Data
text: moment one key function fit_litter can fit 6 different types decomposition trajectories. Note fitted object litfit object can visually compare fits different non-linear equations plot_multiple_fits function:  Calling plot litfit object show data, curve fit, even equation, estimated coefficients:  summary litfit object show summary statistics fit. litfit object can see uncertainty parameter estimate bootstrapping
code: fit <- fit_litter(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),                   mass.remaining =c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),                   model="weibull",                   iters=500)  class(fit) plot_multiple_fits(time=c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),                    mass.remaining=c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),                    model=c("neg.exp","weibull"),                    iters=500) plot(fit) #> Summary of litFit object #> Model type: weibull  #> Number of observations:  7  #> Parameter fits: 4.19  #> Parameter fits: 2.47  #> Time to 50% mass loss: 3.61  #> Implied steady state litter mass: 3.71 in units of yearly input  #> AIC:  -3.8883  #> AICc:  -0.8883  #> BIC:  -3.9965

what: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
text: Non-linear fits different models decomposition trajectory one cohort (typical litterbag studies) data. Models range simple (easy fit limited data) complex.

title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
code: fit_litter(   time,   mass.remaining,   model = c("neg.exp", "weibull", "discrete.parallel", "discrete.series", "cont.quality",     "neg.exp.limit"),   iters = 500,   upper = NULL,   lower = NULL,   ... )

title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
text: time time since decomposition began, , ti-t0 mass.remaining proportional mass loss, , mi/m0 model five models currently implemented (see ) iters Number random starts fitting.  Use higher numbers models larger numbers parameters models inherently tend less identifiable. upper, lower Optional user specified values upper lower bounds used optim fitting procedure. Use care, minimal sanity checking currently implemented. ... Additional arguments passed optim

title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
text: returns litfit object following elements: optimFit: list generated optim function logLik: log-likelihood model time: vector time (input) mass: vector os mass remaining (input) predicted: predicted values model points within time model: name model nparams: number fit parameters model AIC: AIC model fit AICc: AICc model fit BIC: BIC model fit potentially useful things

title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
text: model likelihood maximized using methods available optim.  Optimization methods used within optim can specified control object (.e., control$method).  default method L-BFGS-B bounds specific model. model weibull Weibull residence time model–two parameters (Frechet 1927) discrete.parallel Two pools parallel term fraction initial mass pool–three parameter (Manzoni et al. 2012) discrete.series three parameter model possibility two sequential pools (Manzoni et al. 2012) cont.quality (Ågren Bosatta 1996, see also Manzoni et al. 2012) Warning: difficulty finding optimal solution determined interaction nature complexity likelihood space (data- model-dependent) well optimization methods.  can never guarantee optimal solution found, using many random starting points increase odds.  noted significant variation among models identifiability, models inherently less identifiable likely due tendency form flat ridges likelihood space.  confidence fit low cases (see Cornwell Weedon 2013).   number random starting points used optimization given iters.  function checks whether top 10 optimizations converged likelihood, function return warning.

title: Fit different models to single cohort decomposition data — fit_litter
text: Ågren, G. Bosatta, E. (1996) Quality: bridge theory experiment soil organic matter studies. Oikos, 76, 522–528. Cornwell, W. K., J. T. Weedon. (2013).  Decomposition trajectories diverse litter types: model selection analysis. Methods Ecology Evolution. Frechet, M. (1927) Sur la loi de probabilite de lecart maximum. Ann de la Soc polonaise de Math, 6, 93–116. Manzoni, S., Pineiro, G., Jackson, R. B., Jobbagy, E. G., Kim, J. H., & Porporato, . (2012). Analytical models soil litter decomposition: Solutions mass loss time-dependent decay rates. Soil Biology Biochemistry, 50, 66-76. Olson, J.S. (1963) Energy storage balance producers decomposers ecological systems. Ecology, 44, 322–331.

code: data(pineneedles,package='litterfitter')  plot_multiple_fits(time = pineneedles$Year, mass.remaining = pineneedles$Mass.remaining, bty = 'n', model = c('neg.exp', 'weibull'), xlab = 'Time', ylab = 'Proportion mass remaining',iters=200) #> Number of successful fits:  193  out of 200  #> Number of successful fits:  200  out of 200  #> Warning: May not have found global best fit; increase iterations

code: predict_from_fit(model_fn, params, target_time)

title: Predict Using a Specific Model Function — predict_from_fit
text: model_fn function representing model used prediction. params list parameters passed model function. target_time numeric value representing target time prediction.

title: Predict Using a Specific Model Function — predict_from_fit
text: Numeric. predicted value computed model function.

what: Simulate and Check Model Fitting with Litter Data — simulate_and_check
title: Simulate and Check Model Fitting with Litter Data — simulate_and_check
text: internal function first fits model pineneedles data litterfitter package using fit_litter function. Next, introduces random noise mass remaining data refits model perturbed data. function returns whether time proportion mass remaining values two fits within ten percent .

title: Simulate and Check Model Fitting with Litter Data — simulate_and_check
code: simulate_and_check(model)

title: Simulate and Check Model Fitting with Litter Data — simulate_and_check
text: model character string representing model type fitted using fit_litter.

title: Simulate and Check Model Fitting with Litter Data — simulate_and_check
text: Logical. TRUE time proportion mass remaining values original simulated fits within ten percent ; FALSE otherwise.

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
text: Estimate Steady State Biomass

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
code: steady_state(x = NULL, pars = NULL, model = NULL)

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
text: x litfit object. provided, pars model parameters extracted object. pars numeric vector parameters model. needed x provided. model character string specifying decomposition model. Must one following: "neg.exp", "weibull", "discrete.parallel", "discrete.series", "cont.quality2". needed x provided.

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
text: named numeric value representing estimated steady state biomass specified model.

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
text: Computes steady state biomass, proportion annual input, based given model fit parameters. Currently, function supports subset decomposition models. New model support planned future updates.

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
text: Cornwell

title: Estimate Steady State Biomass — steady_state
code: # Example with litfit object fit <- fit_litter(   time = c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6),   mass.remaining = c(1,0.9,1.01,0.4,0.6,0.2,0.01),   model = 'neg.exp',   iters = 250 ) #> Number of successful fits:  248  out of 250  steady_state(fit) #> neg.exp  #> 4.60503   # Example with specific model and parameter values steady_state(pars = c(6,2), model = "weibull") #>  weibull  #> 5.317362

code: time_to_prop_mass_remaining(x,threshold.mass=0.5)

text: x litfit object threshold.mass mass loss threshold proportion, default 0.5

title: Get the predicted time until half mass loss for a litter decomposition trajectory — time_to_prop_mass_remaining

title: Get the predicted time until half mass loss for a litter decomposition trajectory — time_to_prop_mass_remaining
text: Cornwell

title: Get the predicted time until half mass loss for a litter decomposition trajectory — time_to_prop_mass_remaining
code: fit<-fit_litter(time=pineneedles$Year,mass.remaining=pineneedles$Mass.remaining,  model='neg.exp',iters=1000) #> Number of successful fits:  974  out of 1000   time_to_prop_mass_remaining(fit, threshold.mass = 0.5) #> [1] 2.4932
